docs.snippet: The new United Nations administrator of the Serbian province, Michael Steiner, said rival political parties should ''get their act together'' on forming a government. After an election in November, a new assembly and government were supposed to ta...
docs.lead_paragraph: The new United Nations administrator of the Serbian province, Michael Steiner, said rival political parties should ''get their act together'' on forming a government. After an election in November, a new assembly and government were supposed to take over day-to-day administration while the United Nations retains overall authority. But the main Albanian parties been unable to overcome their differences. Kosovo has been under international control since NATO's 1999 bombing campaign to halt Serbian mistreatment of ethnic Albanians.
docs.abstract: New United Nations administrator of Kosovo province, Michael Steiner, says rival political parties should overcome their differences and form government (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Shape Up, New u.N. Man Says

docs.snippet: After many delays, the government appointed 18 judges to oversee various human rights trials including the trial of 19 people -- some of them generals -- accused of atrocities when East Timor voted for independence in 1999. It was not clear when t...
docs.lead_paragraph: After many delays, the government appointed 18 judges to oversee various human rights trials including the trial of 19 people -- some of them generals -- accused of atrocities when East Timor voted for independence in 1999. It was not clear when the trials would begin. Seth Mydans (NYT)
docs.abstract: Government of Indonesia appoints 18 judges to oversee various human rights trials including trial of 19 people--some of them generals--accused of atrocities when East Timor voted for independence in 1999 (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Judges Named For Rights Trials

docs.snippet: ''Operation Babylift,'' the 1975 transport of 2,700 orphaned or abandoned Vietnamese children to the United States, was regarded by many as a noble rescue, by others as paternalistic intervention. Either way, it proved to be a tragically emblemati...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Operation Babylift,'' the 1975 transport of 2,700 orphaned or abandoned Vietnamese children to the United States, was regarded by many as a noble rescue, by others as paternalistic intervention. Either way, it proved to be a tragically emblematic coda to the Vietnam War. The first plane out, carrying 330 adults and children, crashed 15 minutes after takeoff, killing 154 of its passengers. But the rest of the children, many of them the offspring of American fathers and Vietnamese mothers, survived their journeys. While Vietnam was imprinted on many of their faces, as they grew up it would seem a distant place.
docs.abstract: Julie Salamon reviews Precious Cargo, PBS documentary on return to Vietnam of orphaned and abandoned children airlifted out of country in 1975 (M)

headline.main: When Those Orphaned by War Return to Vietnam

docs.snippet: Thousands of Angolans sang and danced through the rutted streets of the capital last week to celebrate a cease-fire that may finally end nearly a quarter-century of war. But even as the nation rejoiced, it was clear that its fragile peace rested u...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of Angolans sang and danced through the rutted streets of the capital last week to celebrate a cease-fire that may finally end nearly a quarter-century of war. But even as the nation rejoiced, it was clear that its fragile peace rested uneasily on the shoulders of one man. That man is Gen. Paulo Lukamba, the new leader of the Unita rebels, who spent much of last week trying to consolidate support within his party and to dispel lingering doubts that he would keep his guerrillas from returning to their guns.
docs.abstract: Thousands of Angolans sing and dance in rutted streets of capital to celebrate cease-fire that could end nearly quarter-century of war, but fragile peace rests uneasily in hands of Gen Paulo Lukamba, new leader of Unita rebels, who is trying to consolidate support and dispel doubts that he will keep fighters from returning to battle; economic profile; photo; map; graph (M)

headline.main: Angola's Fragile Peace Rests On a New Guerrilla Leader

docs.snippet: Israeli tanks rolled into Gaza City and missiles were fired for a second day at Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah as the Israeli Army kept up a fierce offensive today in retaliation for the killing of six Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on Tue...
docs.lead_paragraph: Israeli tanks rolled into Gaza City and missiles were fired for a second day at Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah as the Israeli Army kept up a fierce offensive today in retaliation for the killing of six Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on Tuesday. Israeli forces also blew up a local radio station in Gaza City and killed 4 Palestinians in the Rafah refugee camp, bringing the number of Palestinians killed in two days of fighting to 22. Another 35 Palestinians were reported wounded in Rafah.
docs.abstract: Israeli Army unleashes fire from ground, sea and air against Palestinian security officers and militants in retaliation for killing of six Israeli soldiers in West Bank; Israeli tanks roll into Gaza City and missiles are fired for second day at Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah; Israeli forces also blow up local radio station in Gaza City and kill 4 Palestinians in refugee camp, bringing number of Palestinians killed in two days of fighting to 22; airstrikes hit Palestinian security installations in Khan Yunis, Rafah and Gaza City; Palestinian leaders appeal to United Nations Security Council to condemn Israeli attacks, even as they vow to continue their fight until Israel leaves West Bank and Gaza Strip, lands it captured in 1967 war; Israeli officials say Palestinians are broadening 16-month-long conflict, combining violence of suicide bombers in Israeli cities and intensifying guerrilla war against soldiers in West Bank and Gaza; photos; map (M)

headline.main: Israel Steps Up Counterstrikes; 22 Arabs Slain

docs.snippet: The Bosnian Serb Democratic Party expelled its founder, Dr. Radovan Karadzic, and all other war crimes suspects today and called for ethnic harmony in a drive to reform its arch-nationalist image.    But Muslims and Croats in Bosnia's sometimes cl...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bosnian Serb Democratic Party expelled its founder, Dr. Radovan Karadzic, and all other war crimes suspects today and called for ethnic harmony in a drive to reform its arch-nationalist image. But Muslims and Croats in Bosnia's sometimes clumsy joint government dismissed the move as a superficial bid to placate the West, which is pressing the Serbian Republic in Bosnia to hand over war crimes fugitives and cooperate with its former wartime enemies.
docs.abstract: Bosnian Serb Democratic Party expels founder Radovan Karadzic and all other war crimes suspects and calls for ethnic harmony; but Mulims and Croats in Bosnia's joint government dismiss move as superficial bid to placate West, which is pressing Serbs in Bosnia to hand over war crimes fugitives and cooperate with former wartime enemies (M)

headline.main: Hoping to Change Its Image, Bosnian Serb Party Expels Karadzic

docs.snippet: A former mathematics teacher who became a prison warden in Bosnia was sentenced to seven and a half years for aiding and abetting war crimes in 1992 and 1993. Judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal said Milorad Krnojelac, 61, a Bosnian S...
docs.lead_paragraph: A former mathematics teacher who became a prison warden in Bosnia was sentenced to seven and a half years for aiding and abetting war crimes in 1992 and 1993. Judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal said Milorad Krnojelac, 61, a Bosnian Serb who was in the Yugoslav Army reserve, had failed to stop guards under his command from abusing hundreds of Muslims at the KP-Dom prison in the town of Foca. Marlise Simons (NYT)
docs.abstract: Milorad Krnojelac, 61, Bosnian Serb teacher who became prison warden, is sentened to more than seven years in prison by UN war crimes tribunal for failing to stop abuse of Muslims at prison in Foca in 1992-1993 (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnia Prison Warden Sentenced

docs.snippet: Secretary General Kofi Annan and international law experts rose to a strong defense of United Nations war crimes tribunals for the Balkans and Rwanda today in response to a broadside attack on them on Thursday by the Bush administration's ambassad...
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary General Kofi Annan and international law experts rose to a strong defense of United Nations war crimes tribunals for the Balkans and Rwanda today in response to a broadside attack on them on Thursday by the Bush administration's ambassador for war crimes. In testimony to Congress, the American war crimes ambassador, Pierre-Richard Prosper, cast doubt on the integrity of the tribunals. ''The professionalism of some personnel has been called into question, with allegations of mismanagement and abuse,'' he said.
docs.abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan and international law experts strongly defend UN war crimes tribunals for Balkans and Rwanda, in response to US envoy Pierre-Richard Prosper's testimony to Congress casting doubt on tribunals' integrity and professionalism; South Africa Justice Richard Goldstone, first chief prosecutor, criticizes Bush administration position that tribunals should wind up work by 2007-2008; experts concede management problems at Rwanda tribunal, but not at Balkan proceedings in The Hague (M)

headline.main: Experts Dispute Bush Aide's Criticism of War Crimes Panels
